title: Nicholas Chang
text:
My name is Nick Chang and I’m a senior in the Department of Environmental Sciences at Emory University! I am currently working on a project describing microhabitat use in the Talladega seal salamander (Desmognathus cheaha), a newly described species of plethodontid salamander. I am interested broadly in biogeography, spatial ecology, and shifts in habitat suitability resulting from anthropogenic change. While I am open to working in a diverse range of study systems, previous work has given me experience working in forested, freshwater, and coastal ecosystems, and I have a special interest in amphibians, reptiles, plants, and aquatic invertebrates.
As I complete my final year in undergrad, I am looking for opportunities for the future! I am planning on taking a year off before applying for graduate school (both MS and PhD programs), so if you are looking for graduate students or a LTE and have an opportunity please reach out!

title: About

Research Experience







2022-present
Undergraduate Honors Researcher, Emory University
Advisor: Dr. Carolyn Keogh
Habitat use and community ecology in the newly-described Talladega seal salamander (Desmognathus cheaha)


May-Aug 2023
Hollings Scholar, Northwest Fisheries Science Center, NOAA/UW SAFS
Advisors: Drs. Craig Norrie, Paul McElhany, & Shallin Busch
Physiological responses of diploid and triploid farmed Pacific oysters (Crassostrea gigas) to climate stressors


2021-2022
Undergraduate Researcher, Saikawa Laboratory, Emory University
Advisor: Dr. Eri Saikawa
Soil and stream sediment contamination in the metro-Atlanta area


2021-2022
Undergraduate Researcher, Dept. of ENVS, Emory University
Advisor: Dr. John Wegner
